instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Hi,

I have here an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) which was water damaged. (I took pictures before cleaning - please check the attachments)
After removing/replacing the broken stuff (caps, 94AGTJIELC180) and cleaning the corrotion the device booted fine .... it also worked for 2 whole days.

But after trying to run "Diagnose Mode" it stopped working and now I cant even restore the system via USB or internet recovery. (Error -2003F | Progress bar is kinda weird)
Furthermore I cant see the hard drive (SSD) when I press "Option" ... is the SSD/T2 bad?

Note:
DFU restore/repair via apple configurator 2 worked fine .. so no problem overall.

I measured some of the important voltages:
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G2H</SIGNAL> = 12.57v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
[*]<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 3.2V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
[*]<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 5.1V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.8v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1v
[*]<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3_MEM</SIGNAL> = 1.8v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
[/LIST]
After trying "Diagnose Mode" again it says "No issues found." Sadly still not working.

Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Some resistor, or trace affected by corrosion.
Can also be accumulated crap under a BGA chip.

SSD is not visible in boot menu, if doesn't have bootable partition.
Can you access it in Target Disk mode?
It should be good, if passed DFU restore.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Picture "4.jpg" is the <CHIP>U3701</CHIP> (WiFi/BT Chip).

Yeah I can enable the "Target Disk mode" (via "T") but the disk wont show up on my second mac (MacBook Pro M1).
Already checked in hard disk utility only the internal SSD of the working mac is available.
Note: Connected via OEM apple cable (not THB).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Same cable used for DFU should serve for Target Disk.
Are you syill able to do DFU restore (not revive)?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Tried it but still won't show up in "Disk Utility" or via command "sudo diskutil list".
Yeah DFU restore is working fine :/ After the restore I get a "question mark" symbol, which is normal.

When I connect an USB drive (with macOS installer on it, used the tutorial from apple) why does it go back to the "internet recovery"?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
T2 machines don't boot from USB, because of security settings.
In recovery mode, adjust Startup Security Utility, if want that.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message: How? I can't get into recovery mode?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
You've said board goes back to Internet recovery.
Do you get the top menu bar?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message: Yeah internet recovery with a progress bar which ends with an error. (No top menu bar)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Disconnect internal LCD and try with external monitor.
Also disconnect the touchbar and touch ID.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
LCD, TouchBar and TouchID (board) disconnected but it won‚Äôt show up anything on the external display.
Now I have the TouchBar and TouchID (board) disconnected but it‚Äôs the same behavior while restoring via ‚ÄúInternet Recovery‚Äù - Result Error -2003F.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message: Must be T2 internal problem then...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message: F*ck that T2 they are so fragile ‚Ä¶.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
May also be a problem with the SSD; as you can't see it in target Disk mode.
However, this board may have a "second life" as donor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
All respekt for any solution you‚Äôve discussed but as 2informaticos write there is/could be corrosion on traces resistors and even under BGA chips. It is a very corroded/infected logicboard and will have issues in future. In
9 out 10 of -2003F failures I solved with known good topcase. I do not say that this is your solution but even today I have solved such an issue by installing the Logic into a known good top. (Even I Can not see any defekts)ü§∑üòÖ. Is it important data on board Or else I would offer the client a spare logicboard and use yours as donor‚ò∫Ô∏è. Greetings Morten

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) - Cant restore system via USB or internet recovery
threads.message:
Hi Morten,

thanks for your reply! :)
Sadly the topcase got already replaced by apple, the issue is still there.

No important data on it, so I have a new donor board. :)
